hobby.message: Any new mods on your FPV quad?
Antique typewriters and quiet bars — good pair.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Just a drink and some quiet tonight.
Not the kind of place for cameras, anyway.
My hobby stays offline, especially after last week.
City’s got enough eyes already.
Don’t worry, I keep my photography low-profile.
Analog only—no digital traces, that’s my rule.
Ever since the crackdown, I trust lenses less than people.
Spent last Friday hiding my film after a drone sweep.
Photographing Stenograd’s mood is trickier these days.
Film photography’s my thing—35mm, real grain, no metadata at all.
I shoot the city when no one’s watching, especially during chaos.
That crackdown last weekend? Lost half a roll dodging drones.
It’s the only way to catch truth they can’t erase.
State hates unfiltered stories—so I keep mine close.
Developed the latest batch in my bathtub, just to be safe.
I’m hooked on street photography—analog only, always grainy, always honest.
Sneaked shots of protest graffiti near the Council right after curfew.
Nearly got my camera confiscated last week when they swept the bar.
I stash my negatives in hollowed books—learned from my old man.
Drones make it hard, but people are braver than they look.
State can’t scrub what isn’t digital—that’s my edge.
Documenting resistance might be the only truth we’ve got left.
You know I’m obsessed with 35mm film—been at it since before the BCI.
Old habits. My dad was a compliance officer, always scolded me for ‘archiving risk’.
Last Friday, shot the blackout crowds—faces flickering by lantern light after the BCI shutdown.
Nearly dropped my camera hiding from Directorate sweeps nearby.
These days, every roll feels like contraband. Developing’s half the thrill.
I’ve taught three people in the neighborhood how to use a darkroom.
If the state ever finds my negatives, they’ll see the things they’re trying to erase.
Sometimes I think I’m building a record for the day we finally get the truth back.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still at it when I can.
Supplies are harder to find now.
Too many eyes out after the last crackdown.
Mostly stick to safe spots these days.
You never know who's listening anymore.
Still getting my shots in, just more carefully.
Film’s trickier to source since the new restrictions.
After the sweeps, too many places feel risky.
Everybody’s more on edge, sharing less.
I mostly work alone now.
The crackdown really changed the city’s mood.
Analog’s the only way I trust what I’m seeing.
Film’s almost currency after those detention raids.
After BCI locked down communications, sharing prints got risky.
Some shots now feel like evidence, not just art.
I caught Ministry tape crews chasing protestors last week.
Developing’s slower—have to keep everything hidden.
Whole hobby feels less innocent these days.
Analog keeps me honest—what the city really looks like, not doctored.
Since Directorate seized digital records, film’s my protest.
A lot of my favorite spots turned into checkpoint zones overnight.
Had a run-in with a patrol near the market, camera in my jacket.
Odd how a photo can make you a suspect now.
Even street labs won’t touch negatives if protests are in them.
Started swapping prints in the back rooms, under the radar.
Feels like every shot matters more, dangerous or not.
Always. Analog’s truth, even when it’s risky now.
My dad was a BCI officer—taught me a lens can’t lie, but reports can.
When Halden’s death cracked the system, I started documenting missing faces—neighbors, regulars, even Council staff.
Patrols sweep the alleys; I stash negatives in old HVAC ducts downtown.
Last week, compliance drones tailed me leaving Bar 101—never happened before crackdown.
Film costs triple, and everyone’s nervous to share, but it’s worth it.
Caught a secret rendezvous on film—the kind that gets erased everywhere else.
Sometimes I feel like I’m stealing pieces of the city before they disappear.
If they find my archive, it’s more than photos—it’s the city’s memory.
